labels.label: Label
labels.subject: LC Subject Heading
labels.import: Import MODS Record From Catalog Key

alerts.displayLabel: All local identifiers should have a display label to qualify the identifier.
alerts.title: Take title from cassette label, but correct misspellings and spell out abbreviated words. Omit initial articles from this field (a, an, the for English) and instead put them in the Non-Sorting Characters field.
alerts.nonSort: In this field put initial articles (a, an, the for English) which are the first word of the Title.
alerts.titletype: Leave blank for the main title. If there is a spoken title or other variant that is different from the main title, add another Title Information field and record that as a Title type Alternative.
alerts.partnumber: Only use if the lecture is numbered as part of a series of different lectures with the same title. Do not use for the different parts of the same lecture (as in tape 1, side 1 etc.)
alerts.typeofresource: Please select a type of resource.
alerts.date: Dates must be in YYYY-MM-DD format.
alerts.physicaldescription: All records must contain one Physical Description element
alerts.url: All records require one URL entry in http:// or https:// format
alerts.accesscondition: All records must contain an Access Condition entry.
alerts.nameauthority: All records must contain a authority for all name elements.

help.identifier: At least one identifer is required. The DLF/Aquifer Implementation Guidelines for Shareable Metadata Records recommend the use of at least one identifier element with the type attribute containing appropriate values in each MODS record. This element is repeatable.
help.identifiertype: Required. All occurrences of the identifier element must contain the type attribute to indicate the type of the identifier. If a local identifier is used, it should be indicated as such using the local value.
help.displayLabel: Identifiers marked as "local" should have a qualifer to describe the identifer type.
help.title: Take title from cassette label, but correct misspellings and spell out abbreviated words. Omit initial articles from this field (a, an, the for English) and instead put them in the Non-Sorting Characters field.
help.titletype: All additional titles must designate a type.
help.titleInfo: The DLF/Aquifer Implementation Guidelines for Shareable MODS Records require the use in all records of at least one titleInfo element with one title subelement. Other subelements of titleInfo are recommended when they apply. This element is repeatable.
help.subtitle: The subtitle element is used to record a part of a title deemed secondary to the core portion. The guidelines recommend the use of this element when a subtitle is present, rather than including the subtitle in the text of the title element. When using the subTitle element, do not include punctuation at the end of the title element intended to delineate the title from the subtitle.
help.nonSort: The nonSort element contains characters, including initial articles, punctuation, and spaces that appear at the beginning of a title that should be ignored for indexing of titles. The guidelines strongly recommend the use of this element when non-sorting characters are present, rather than including them in the text of the title element. Examples include : 'The' or 'A'. Do not include these character in the title field, but rather include them only in the nonSort field.
help.partname: The partName element is used for a part or section name of a title. Use partName to describe the section or division titles of the digital object (for example, a chapter title, episode name, or an audio or video clip). The guidelines recommend the use of this subelement when a part name is present, rather than including the part name in the text of the title element. When using the partName element, do not include punctuation at the end of the preceding element intended to delineate the part name from previous parts of the title.
help.partnumber: The partNumber element is used for a part or section number of a title. partNumber may describe the section of the digital object (for example, an episode number or an audio or video clip). partNumber may follow title or subTitle as appropriate. The guidelines recommend the use of this subelement when a part number is present, rather than including the part number in the text of the title element. When using the partNumber element, do not include punctuation at the end of the preceding element intended to delineate the part number from previous parts of the title.
help.typeofresource: For the purposes of records created according to these guidelines, information in typeOfResource is about the original item. For example, in the case of a digitized photograph, typeOfResource would apply to the analog original; in born-digital materials, it would apply to the original digital format.
help.date: If the date is not given on the cassette label or spoken on the tape, attempt to estimate a date, or google the title in an attempt to see when the program was given. A range of dates such as a decade may be given by clicking the second “Creation Date button and putting the earliest date in the Start, and latest name in the end.
help.qualifier: Only add a qualifier if the exact date is not given and a date was inferred, approximate, or questionable.
help.place: Record in place names associated with the creation or issuance of a resource. Place should be omitted if no information about the originating place of the resource is known.
help.publisher: Publisher is a named entity determined to be the publisher or originator for a resource. Descriptive standards such as AACR2 may be used to format the name of the publisher. Information about an institution responsible for digitizing and delivering online a previously published resource should be included in note, rather than in publisher.
help.subject: Use LC subject headings when a subject can be ascertained. Where a topical LC subject is subdivided by a topic, as in “Motion pictures—Production and direction,” put both in a single Topic field, divided by two hypens with no spaces before or after. Headings or subdivisions for geographic places, personal or corporate names, or dates should be put in the appropriate subject subfields as indicated on the buttons. For geographic places that are cities, input in the format State—City (for US or Canadian provinces) or Country—City (for non-US places)
help.edition: The edition element is used to provide an edition statement for a published work. Descriptive standards such as AACR2 and DACS may be used to determine if an edition statement should be recorded and in what format. If no edition statement applies to the resource, do not include the edition element.
help.name: For personal names, input as Last name, First name, as in Smith, John. Do not put in a Name Type for this. If a name has associated life dates or a term of address, add another Name Part field. Put the name in the Name Part field that has no associated Name Type, and put the date or term of address in the one with the Name Type, and choose the appropriate type (usually “date”).
help.nameauthority: Use Local unless the Library of Congress NAF file is checked.
help.namerole: Use this subelement to actually contain the coded or textual description. At the time the guidelines are published there is only one: the MARC Value List for Relators and Roles.
help.genre: The genre element is recommended in these guidelines and should be used to characterize the content of the digital resource rather than the digital resource itself.
help.form: This subelement specifies the physical form or medium of the material for a resource. This list include values from Source Codes for Forms (smd) maintained by the Library of Congress.
help.internetmediatype: This subelement records the electronic format type of the digital resource. Since it is expected that records shared for the Aquifer initiative describe resources existing in digital versions, at least one internetMediaType is required. This element has no attributes. The content value for this subelement should be taken from the MIME Media Types list and expressed in the format type/subtype. If a digital resource comprises multiple file types (for example, a diary that has been imaged and a text transcription made available), use a separate internetMediaType subelement for each.
help.extent: This subelement includes a statement of the number and specific material of the units of the resource that express physical extent. It has no attributes. The use of your content standard of choice is strongly recommended if this subelement is used.
help.digitalorigin: Record here the method by which a resource achieved digital form. Content values for this subelement are defined in the MODS schema. Resources incorporating pre-existing analog content with new digital content should be recorded as "born digital".
help.url: This subelement contains the Uniform Resource Location (URL) for the resource. The URL provided should be persistent.
help.urlaccess: This attribute helps a metadata aggregator determine what a URL is likely to link to and can help determine which URL to use for specific purposes.
help.physicallocation: Use this subelement to identify the institution or repository holding the resource, or from which it is available. Within these guidelines, it identifies the physical, institutional home of an analog resource that has been digitized.
help.accesscondition: The audience for rights relating to possible uses of digital resources is the end user, so rights information should be as free of legalese and technical jargon as possible. State clearly any restrictions on use of the digital resource, including explicitly mentioning lack of copyright restrictions when the digital resource is in the public domain. Also provide contact information for use by end users who wish to pursue required permissions for publication, exhibit, or other types of dissemination. If you maintain rights information relating to specific digital resources on a web site, you may wish to provide a URL for that web site in lieu of a textual rights statement. When doing so, you should provide enough textual explanation, along with the URL, to make the purpose of the URL clear to end users. Whenever possible, consider using a standard license such as Creative Commons and/or a rights expression language such as the Open Digital Rights Language (ODRL) specification. In cases where access to a resource is unrestricted, a statement should appear that says so.
help.accessconditiontype: Use the type attribute to indicate restrictions (or lack thereof) on use of the resource and/or restrictions on access to the material. Use restrictionOnAccess only to indicate access restrictions (such as those based on institution affiliation or age) rather than restrictions on use. Other sorts of restrictions, such as government classification, should have no type attribute.
help.abstract: Record a succinct summary of the content of the digital resource. When creating a MODS record for a digital surrogate, record a summary of the content of the original resource. If only a portion of the resource was digitized, summarize only that portion. This element provides end users with information about the digital resource that assists them in making a judgment about its likely usefulness, and also provides context, if needed, for controlled vocabulary used in the record. The use of your content standard of choice is strongly recommended.
